column3: List details on the top Digital and IT transformation projects driven by you and the impact/ financials of each. Give examples of challenges faced and solutions.
column4:
Single version of Truth: IFFCO had multiple legacy ERP systems due to acquisitions in different countries.  The real challenge for the board was to get reliable and trustworthy information in a timely manner from different businesses across the globe.  When I joined IFFCO group, I created a program with a vision to arrive at a single version of truth through implementation of a common ERP system across the group (20+ countries, 6 business verticals, approx. 2000 users).  There was a need to get the buy in from key business leaders even though there was a top down mandate from the board. I worked with the key business leaders and communicated clearly the benefits of the program, especially the specific analytics dashboards which will help them with their day to day decision making in a very competitive business environment.  The quality of data available in various legacy systems was very poor.  To succeed in an ERP implementation, there is a need to have good quality master data right at the beginning. I created a dedicated track and a team just to focus on this.  It really helped to make sure that the go live was not hindered due to data quality issues.  I created a formal governance structure for monitoring and review which ensured that the program was on track and the decisions were made as soon as the need arose.  This was slightly different from the informal governance which existed previously in the organisation and required considerable influencing from my side to bring about the change.  Along with the central ERP implementation there were other tracks to cater to analytics, mobile applications (for approvals, workflows, reports, dashboards, etc.), integration with third party businesses, cloud HR systems, etc.  Each track was run independently under the umbrella program at the group level.

SAP Rating on Project management - 4
SAP Rating on Strategic Planning - 4
column5:
Several years ago Unilever decided to close its data centers and move all its IT systems to cloud. Microsoft Azure was selected for hosting SAP systems and Google cloud was selected for non SAP systems. Moving to Microsoft Azure meant moving from IBM power systems with AIX OS to  Intel based systems running  Linux. When we initiated the project, largest successful migration of an ECC system was 2 Terra Byte. One Company attempted to migrate a 5TB ECC system, but ended up cancelling their project after several attempts. We had 4 ECC systems with sizes ranging between 20 & 35 TB. 
There were many challenges we had to overcome but I can group under below headings.
1)	Functionality must stay the same
2)	Performance should be at least as good as on premise.
3)	Functioning data center base services (such as back up  restore, authentication, network etc)
4)	No negative impact to live system during preparation of the shadow system in cloud 
5)	Migration must be completed within 36 hours of down time and must not leave anything behind.
We had to overcome all these challenges by performing many different tests & simulations, corrections, developing tools and approaches, finding work arounds, enhancing tools available in the market. 
It will take pages to explain each challenge and how we overcome those. At the end we were able to complete 4 largest ever ECC migrations to cloud successfully. Project was recognized as a great success in multiple forums within Microsoft, Unilever, Accenture.
Cost of the project was double digit million Euros.
I will provide 2 specific examples just to give a flavor,
1)	During the first ECC migration, basis consultant from SI made two mistakes in the process. First one caused the down time to be increased by 4 hours and Second mistake resulted some data integrity issues on a specific table. I had to manage stake holders from 50 countries which were becoming impatient due to not being able to resume operations after 36 hours outage, and at the same time worked with SAP to assess the extent of risk due to mismatch on that table. At the end we were able to recreate that table retrospectively but had to lock a few transactions until that table was corrected. 
I was able to comfort 200+ impatient business and IT stake holders from all around the world on a MS teams call and convince them to give technical team some more time to fix forward the problem. I explained that if we had rolled back immediately, it would cost another outage of 36 hours for business and would have a knock-on effect on the following migrations which would delay Data Center closure, costing a fortune to Unilever.  My boss, who was new to Unilever at the time, was very much impressed with the way I managed the crisis. 

2)	5-6 hours after moving our first ECC production system to cloud, we started to experience severe performance problem when number of active users exceeded 5000. Microsoft was responsible from the hardware and architecture. To address the problem they moved our service to the largest frame, but it did not improve the situation. I advised them to look for bottlenecks in the system and asked them to show me the storage architecture. I noticed that they used a single disk for keeping Database logs. I instructed them to replace that disk with 8 fastest disks available with striping. As soon as that was done performance problem was eliminated.
column6:
SAP Rating on Project management - 4
SAP Rating on Strategic Planning - 3
Shiva Nair has a proven track record of driving business transformation and delivering exceptional technology and business leadership. He has led several digital and IT transformation projects throughout his career. Here are some of the top Digital and IT Transformation initiatives at Agthia, Adani and Pfizer :
 SAP HANA Implementation: Shiva spearheaded the first five successful implementations of SAP HANA 1709 and 2021 in India and in the GCC region, introducing innovative technology solutions that significantly contributed to business revenue and growth. This project helped Agthia and Adani Wilmar move towards its business goal by reaping early business benefits in the areas of supply chain, manufacturing, and customer engagement. The extensive use of SAP Fiori enabled transactions on mobile devices.
Full Digitalization Agenda: At Agthia Group PJSC, Shiva led the Full Digitalization agenda, focusing on unlocking value, supporting group ambitions, enabling digital-first approaches, and enhancing cybersecurity posture through a comprehensive Security Maturity Roadmap to safeguard company data and information across diverse platforms. This project aimed to enable a digital-first approach to consumers/customers and end-to-end operations, thus enabling future M&A integrations and synergy extraction, further optimizing the existing business, and fueling regional expansion opportunities.Cloud Adoption: Shiva defined and executed an Integrated Cloud Strategy aimed at enhancing IT and business efficiencies, fostering enterprise-wide revenue growth, and driving innovation across the organization, resulting in optimized costs and increased operational efficiencies. The Agthia Cloud provided a business transformation platform that enabled cost optimization, business efficiency, and revenue growth, supporting Agthia's Strategic Vision. The project yielded IT cost optimization through re-negotiation and solution optimization for 6 business entities. Complex IT acquisition and integration processes, consolidating IT divisions, applications, infrastructure, security protocols, and governance frameworks led to achieve synergies and operational efficiencies across the group. 
Covid-19: Technology at the “Front and Centre“ driving revenues and business continuity: During the onset of the lockdown, at Adani Wilmar, introduced a Cognitive Artificial Intelligent (AI) Order taking BOT for taking product orders from Societies, Consumers, Retailers, Hotel, Restaurant and Bakery. This has delivered essential products to the nation during the Covid-19 situation and has contributed to yielding additional revenue streams. Headed the introduction of a Retailer App which enables Retailers to place order irrespective of salesman’s availability. Helped sustain business revenues in the Covid-19 scenario where market working was not feasible. Strategized and Implemented a state-of-the-art infrastructure to create a robust, secure and seamlessly connected environment for Adani Wilmar business to grow. Approx. 10,000 colleagues and contractors were able to seamlessly switch to remote working overnight and securely conduct business.
Commercial Business Intelligence:  Initiated the use of Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning and Advanced Analytics, enabled the business to drive efficiencies and deliver better business outcomes. Project Chanakya (Adani Wilmar) provides one view of performance across multiple dimensions. Chanakya is now providing the sales colleagues with business insights by identifying exceptions and deviations and aiding in reasoning these out. – From Insights to Action, in real-time. Project KANZ (in Arabic it means Treasure) at Agthia Group, C-Suite gets previous days KPIs on fingertips with CXO Dashboards. This improved decision-making frequency from Months to days, which showed significant positive impact on Top Line. Directed efforts to enhance Business Analytics Processes, aligning with Annual Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) to ensure the organization's data-driven decision-making capabilities were continually optimized. Annual Savings of AED 917,000At Pfizer, Strategized and implemented the “Panorama Commercial Dashboard” to provide one view of business performance across multiple dimensions thereby providing sales personnel insight into market trends. This initiative garnered the 2016 Unleashing Regional APAC Award and became a global best practice.
The common challenges faced during the implementations of key initiatives at Agthia, Adani and Pfizer were primarily:
Change management, 
Leadership and business unit customer alignment
ensuring user adoption, and mitigating risks associated with technology
digital maturity of the different Business Units
Importantly, Challenging the Status Quo on two fronts, 
moving the company forward bi-directionally – “Intuition driven” business to a “data driven” business and 
Adopting industry standard best practices and taking advantage of process changes opportunities during a strategic Business Led – IT transformation
Shiva overcame these challenges by:
Developing and executing a forward-looking IT roadmap, fostering a culture of ownership within the Business Technology organization "everyone helps to sell," , 
Establishing Business+IT governance councils for all IT-enabled business projects (which helped ensure business value realization from investments in technology)
Introducing innovative solutions that drove efficiencies and delivered better business outcomes
He also managed a substantial annual IT budget and a high-performance team to deliver significant business value through innovative technology solutions and strategic IT initiatives. This included strategic partnerships with key principals like Microsoft, SAP, Oracle etc and niche players to partner, invest and bring business value to all the organizations that he has served for
Partnering collaboratively with CEO’s, BU Heads and colleagues at all levels to help them drive and manage change

column3: List down instances where you were personally championing the implementation of enterprise wide solutions. What were the challenges faced and how did you overcome them?
column4:
In IFFCO, there was a need to consolidate financial results coming from different businesses and countries into the central group currency AED.  It was done manually and took many weeks until the last unit could send the financials in the required format.  Based on my prior experience in Tata Consumer, I suggested implementation of SAP BPC (Business Planning & Consolidation) tool.  The finance community in the countries was not used to the transparency that such a tool can provide across the group hierarchy.  Also the new global tool meant timely submission and closing.  The data from ERP went directly to the BPC system.  In the past, the local accountants had the opportunity to massage the data in Excel before sending the sheets to Head Office. Hence there was lot of resistance to this project.  I personally worked with the CFO and Finance Heads to showcase the benefits of having such a system at the group level.  Since I had implemented the same system in Tata Consumer, there was some credibility to what I was conveying.  I also used the consultants to bring the industry experience and potential benefits.  We implemented the system after putting in adequate governance and the project discipline required.  The central system was able to take input from any ERP automatically as well as had an excel/web interface to feed data.  This ensured that the financial integration happened as soon as any new company was acquired anywhere across the globe.

SAP Rating on Leadership and Communication - 4
SAP RAting on Stakeholder engagement - 4
SAP RAting on Stakeholder alignment capability  - 3
column5:
I will refer to my U2K2 experience,
I was responsible from all IT deliverables including design, build, test, integration with up/down stream systems, master data preparation, cutover, go live, post go live support & handing over to business as usual support. Within 5 years and 9 releases, 45 countries  went live. Total number of users reached 18000 at the end of the program. 
I established 2 independent/self-sufficient teams which worked with 6 months phase difference. This allowed me to deliver one major release every 6 months. Each release had to be delivered within 12 months exactly as resources need to be shifting to the following release. Meeting every milestone was critical. 
On the average 250 FTEs were working on the project throughout the roll out. Naturally while delivering such a big program, we have faced many challenges. We had established our implementation methodology at the beginning of the program. After each release went live, we enhanced our methodology with the learnings we had from previous go live so that each new release was a better experience for all. I believe this was one of the main success factors.
Some of the categories of challenges we faced were:
1)	Managing scope
2)	Pushing back requirements which are not in line with SAP fundamentals.
3)	Managing Last minute change Requests.
4)	Making last minute corrections to master data.
5)	Ensuring High Performance of Team
6)	Recovering from setbacks in various deliveries
7)	Risk of missing milestones/gates
8)	Crisis management at go live.
9)	Recovering from major Bill of Material/ Master Data Errors.
10)	Team motivation
11)	Language barriers
12)	Dealing with political unrest in the countries we are operating.
I will elaborate on few of them only:
-1- Managing scope was very critical in being able to deliver the program according to planned schedule. We needed to make sure that all project milestones were achieved 100%, so that we didn’t impact the plans of the following release. In earlier releases, we were not as successful in managing the scope and my team had to work very hard to deliver increased scope. That resulted burn out of team members and resulted higher number of defects after go live. 
Based on these learnings, I adapted the methodology and started to specify the scope and amount of deviation I can accommodate without compromising quality at the beginning of the release. I showed senior stakeholders of the countries in scope, the statistics about the number of issues faced after go live by a country who stayed within the scope versus with the one which kept adding last minute requirements. I made them speak with their peers in previous countries. I also introduced “Post Go Live Support Change Request” concept. With this scheme, I created a small capacity for delivering the required additional functionality after go live by a separate team without impacting following releases.
-4-8-9- China was one of our largest countries in the program. During the black out period, it was discovered that China team made a mistake in legacy systems in their product cost calculations which was used in uploading opening balances into SAP. It wouldn’t be possible to go live without correcting all the master data, and it would take several days to complete the correction with conventional methods which would have a huge business impact. I pulled together an “expert team meeting” to find a way to correct the data. We found an approach to correct the data. Since it was outside of our methodology and we could face audit issues later, we described what we would be doing to China CFO and obtained his endorsement. We also used Firefighter which logs every step performed in the operation and we were able to go live with just 6 hours of delay.   

-10 – Team members were unwilling to travel to Pakistan because of safety concerns. I tried to convince the team that Unilever would not risk anyone for any project. I told them that office and hotel was on the same compound, and they would not need to step out to public places. They said they were still afraid and wanted us to purchase life insurance for them, which I did. Even after that there was not enough people to travel to Pakistan. My final solution to the problem was promising that anyone working in Pakistan Release would also be working on Russia-Ukraine-Belarus release (those countries were in peace and very popular destinations at the time), and we ended up with volunteers more than the need.

-12- We faced political unrest in 3 countries (Coup in Thailand, Arab Spring in Egypt, Shopping Mall shootings in Kenya) while our team members were there. We had to manage team members’ safe evacuation; but those stories are for later dinner conversations.
column6:
Shiva Nair has a proven track record of championing the implementation of enterprise-wide solutions in various organizations, including Adani Wilmar Limited, Pfizer India, and Agthia Group PJSC. 

During these implementations, in addition to the key challenges mentioned earlier, he faced several challenges, such as complex IT acquisition and integration processes, carving out IT from Group IT, and introducing new technologies. 

To overcome these challenges, Shiva developed and executed long-term technology and digital strategies, enhanced cybersecurity measures, and assembled high-performance technology teams. For instance, during the integration of five newly acquired companies in diverse regions, he oversaw a meticulous acquisition integration process. Similarly, during the implementation of SAP S4/HANA 2021, he played a key leadership role in the successful implementation of the platform, positioning Agthia as one of the pioneering organizations in the GCC region to leverage the platform for enhanced financial operations, optimized supply chain management, improved manufacturing processes, and elevated customer engagement experiences. 


Shiva has consistently delivered exceptional value, services, and capabilities by blending technical expertise with business acumen to drive business growth and revenue

column3: How do you measure ROI of your interventions and how can you quantify your value addition to the Business/ Organization
column4: Every large IT investment made required that the ROI calculation was mandatorily presented to the board  before the project was approved.  Clear business benefit had to be indentified.  This ensured that all the resources in the organisation were used optimally and it also helped in prioritising investments.  No projects were approved unless they had adequate ROI, except projects which were for regulatory requirements or were focused on risk reduction.  Some examples below. 1.  Monthly closing of books for financial results in 3 days v/s earlier one week.  This ensured that there is manpower savings which can be measured in mandays saved.  It also allowed to take corrective business decisions few days earlier instead of waiting for one week.  2. Improved OTIF (On time In full) measures & headcount savings on implementation of a planning solution.  Both resulted in financial savings.  3. Modern Inventory & Warehouse management system in a factory location resulted in inventory reduction leading to savings in working capital requirements.
column5:
Broadly I can categorize the projects I managed in to 3 categories: 
1)	Mandatory changes such as; legal, compliance, acquisitions, new factories/ warehouses, upgrades.
2)	Business transformations.
3)	IT initiated improvement projects.
For first category we did not calculate ROI.
For second category ROI is calculated based on a wider business case which takes in to account the value transformation delivers. Main benefit contributors were: reduction in inventory levels, improve speed/quality of customer service resulting increased revenues, deliver supply chain efficiencies (better capacity utilization, route optimization, Warehouse efficiency/throughput increase, reduction of waste), reduction in workforce, achieving wider/global visibility for better management & control, etc.
For last category, ROI  is calculated mostly based on 1) IT savings due to improved/more efficient IT solution (reduce the need for computing power/capacity), eliminate bottlenecks 2) Business resource savings which are achieved by reducing the time which business resources spend for doing their day to day operations. All my direct reports had the goal of identifying and delivering a Continuous Improvement Project delivering benefit as much as their cost to company as one of their personal targets every year in addition to their day job.
The largest project/program I delivered (the IT part) was U2K2 program which was rolling out a regional SAP system (including ECC, APO, BW, MDM, PI etc) to 50+ countries in Asia, Australia, Africa & Middle East. There were both IT & Non IT costs. All local legacy ERP systems have been eliminated and truly regional system and processes were established which enabled Unilever to manage entire geography effectively. Program cost was 9 figures in Euros, spanning 5 years. Pay back started in phased manner as countries were rolled in. Main contributors to pay back were Supply Chain optimization (Using factories to source multiple countries, buying efficiencies, improving on shelf availability resulting increased turnover, reduction of inventory at all levels (raw, pack, finished) while improving the service, reducing obsoletes/ waste; Reduction in working capital; Reduction in workforce due to implementation of shared service centers. I can’t share the financial details but business was quite happy to have the program implemented.
column6:
In today's fast-paced business environment, it is essential to measure the Return on Investment (ROI) and quantify the value addition of any initiative. The initiatives outlined in the provided information are no exception. To make a significant impact, it is crucial to focus on tangible results and performance indicators.

To measure the ROI of his interventions, Shiva has managed annual IT budgets of up to USD 13 million (INR 90Cr.) with technology scale to support and drive company revenues of up to USD 4.2 billion (INR 30,000 Cr.). He has also yielded IT cost optimization through re-negotiation and solution optimization, resulting in reduced prices of up to 12% with better service levels and project hours. Shiva's contributions have resulted in increased net sales growth, recruitment of additional domestic customers, and enhanced supply chain efficiency.

The introduction of a new HOD (Home Office Delivery) App and integrated system has fueled further regional growth and increase net sales growth by 12% compared to 2022. Additionally, the implementation of an always-on points/tier retention program, the first of its kind among peers, will reward consumer loyalty and recruit additional domestic customers by 13%. These initiatives demonstrate the potential positive effect on market share and revenue growth.

Standardizing group ERP systems and implementing SAP Analytics Cloud has lead to increased operational efficiencies, financial transparency, and improved forecasting capabilities. This has resulted in a 20% improvement in process efficiency and a reduction in FTE headcount by 50%, leading to significant cost savings. These initiatives have streamlined and integrated the finance platform for the Agthia Group, resulting in a more efficient and effective organization.

The demand and supply planning implementations aim to optimize inventory management and production scheduling, which could potentially drive a 1% increase in overall revenue. Moreover, these efforts seek to elevate the role of Supply Chain within the company, fostering collaboration among various departments and reducing costs by 0.5% in COGS.

To measure the ROI of interventions and quantify value addition to a business or organization, Shiva introduced the requirement of a Business Case which included the investment and the ROI (be it productivity, manpower optimization , cost savings or revenue growth) for every single IT initiative. In addition, Shiva was instrumental in forming a “Business-IT Governance Council for all IT enabled business projects”. The Governing Council objective was to review each initiative for its business benefits and value, and conducting a business value realization exercise post go-live

To maximize the impact of these initiatives, it was essential for Shiva to establish baselines, set clear objectives, monitor progress, evaluate results, communicate findings, and continuously improve. By adhering to these best practices, Shiva has effectively demonstrated the value added by his interventions, ultimately justifying investment decisions and promoting sustainable growth
column7:
Define Objectives and Metrics:
Clearly define the project objectives or initiative. What are you trying to achieve?
Identify the relevant metrics and KPIs that align with the overall goals of the organization.

Baseline Measurement:
Establish a baseline measurement of the current state before implementing the intervention.
This could include performance metrics, cost structures, efficiency levels, or any other relevant factors.

Implementation and Monitoring:
Implement the intervention and closely monitor its progress.
Use project management tools, analytics, and other tracking mechanisms to collect real-time data during the intervention period.

Post-Implementation Measurement:
Measure the outcomes and results after the intervention has been implemented.
Compare the post-implementation metrics with the baseline to assess the changes.

Quantify Financial Impact:
Where possible, quantify the financial impact of the intervention. This could involve calculating cost savings, revenue increases, or any other financial gains.
Consider both direct and indirect financial impacts.

Consider Non-Financial Metrics:
While ROI often involves financial metrics, consider non-financial metrics that also contribute to overall value.
These could include improvements in customer satisfaction, employee engagement, process efficiency, or brand reputation.

Benchmark Against Industry Standards:
Benchmark your organization's performance and ROI against industry standards or best practices.
Understand how your organization compares to others in your industry or sector.

Build a Business Case:
Use the data and results to build a compelling business case.
Clearly articulate the value addition in terms of both financial and non-financial benefits.

Continuous Improvement:
Evaluate the lessons learned during the intervention.
Use feedback and insights to refine strategies and interventions for continuous improvement.

column3: Describe instances where you have grown internally within an organization or instances where the job role was enhanced.
column4: The last two stints were already CXO level roles for me.  I started as Management Trainee in Hindustan Unilever Ltd. and grew to a level of IT Director before I left them. I was part of the small 'lister' community in Hindustan Unilever Ltd. where accelerated growth opportunities were provided and wider exposure to different roles was given in a short span of time.  Due to this, I got to work on all the parts of IT within my time in HUL; viz. Application Development, ERP, Infrastructure and Networking, Information Security, E-Commerce, Helpdesk, Outsourcing, etc.  All along, there was progressive increase in the role compexity and the team size to manage.  The roles grew from the local India roles to regional APAC roles to global ones.
column5: Due to my performance in delivering U2K2 program and establishing the framework for managing it as a platform, my role was extended to cover the platform serving Americas. One year later I took over the responsibility of systems supporting India and managed 3 ERP platforms (of 4) until Unilever decided to outsource AD & AM services for SAP to Accenture India. At that time, I handed over my responsibilities to a colleague in India as I did not want to move to India.
column6:
At Pfizer India, he progressed from a Consultant in Information Technology to a Business Technology Director - CIO (Chief Information Officer). He also served as the Director of Service Delivery - Asia Business Technology and Senior Manager - Technology Services - Business Technology at Pfizer India. 

At Adani Wilmar Limited, he was appointed as the Vice President and CIO (Chief Information Officer). He designed and restructured the new Adani Wilmar IT organization to meet current and future business needs and established a Business+IT Governance Council for all IT-enabled business projects. He also managed a high-performance team of 25 members and an annual IT budget of USD 13 million (INR 90Cr.) with technology scale to support and drive company revenues of USD 4.2 billion (INR 30,000 Cr.). 

At Agthia Group PJSC, he served as the Group & Global Senior IT Director, responsible for driving strategic IT initiatives across the Middle East, North Africa, and South Asia. He managed a substantial AED 50M annual IT budget within a company generating revenues of 4 Billion AED, overseeing a high-performance team of 70 members to deliver significant business value through innovative technology solutions and strategic IT initiatives.
column7: During my Journery at Redington I have grown from a System manager all the way to become the CTO for the region. Last two years I have been involved in global and grouop level projects and decision making for Redington. Always try to bring new tech and application inovation to the organization to serve the business better and keep the business and cost objectives as priority

column3:
From your professional experience, list down instances/ real-life examples involving the below areas:
1. Change Management
2. Risk Management
3. Global and Cross-cultural experience
column4:
1. Change Management: The transport division in IFFCO was using a telematics solution for tracking the 400+ trucks which was old and outdated, but did the basic job well.  The team was comfortable with the solution and wasn’t keen to change it.  My team had done the research and found out a much better solution with newer technology at similar cost.  I went to the Division Head and his leadership team to understand their point of view.  I realised that there was fear of change (unknown) since they were not used to it as a team.  I spoke to them about the benefits, my previous experience with change management and how we can reduce the risk while transitioning. I showed them the new reports and dashboards.  I suggested that we do a quick pilot to prove the technology and the solution before rolling it out to all the trucks.  This was agreed by the team.  In due course, we were able to implement new technology without increasing any cost.  The team accepted the change and were using the system comfortably after that.       2. Risk Management: There was an increased risk of cybersecurity in IFFCO due the multiple global brands' footprint, geographical spread as well as increased incidences of targeted attacks in the Middle East.  Hence it was necessary to create the required infrastructure to protect IFFCO from the malicious attacks.  We created a cybersecurity program which covered all the aspects - Identify, Protect, Detect, Respond & Recover.  There was an extensive cyber awareness program covering all the locations globally.  There was cybersecurity maturity score measured every quarter with clear goals for every year.  This ensured that the cyber risks were adequately addressed.  3. Global & Cross-cultural experience:  When SAP was being implemented in Egypt, there was a need to communicate with the team in Arabic and understand the local culture to ensure that the change is well accepted.  Since the senior management team understood English as well, we took their help while communicating key messages.  The entire training material was replicated in Arabic and we got Arabic speaking consultants to deliver the training as well as handhold the users post go live for two months.  There was extensive training delivered on how to get help from the offshore support team remotely.  With adequate planning and care, such cross cultural and language barriers can be easily overcome in a global organisation.
SAP Rating on 
Change management - 4
Risk Management - 4
Global and Cross-cultural experience -4
column5:
1)	Change Management
Change Management is a critical success factor for ERP implementations. It is necessary to 
 i) show the end user experience of the new set up and how it will benefit the users, 
ii) help users learn the new process and solution with the appropriate support materials and tools. 
iii)  be supported with specific soft change management activities appropriate for the culture of the company/country.
During my U2K2 program, I ensured that high quality training materials were prepared with quick reference cards, simulations, video recordings, functioning training environment and a good training team (formed via train the trainer approach) which then evolved in to key user network. Even though it costed a lot, we ensured the availability of the training materials in local languages, as typical ERP users were not proficient in English.
-There were  individuals who had developed competencies in the legacy systems, and they were unwilling to make the effort for learning how to work with SAP. I explained them that they will become more valuable to the company and external market as the whole world is using SAP.
-There were people whose jobs/roles were eliminated due to the transformation. If you didn’t manage those well, they might have undermined the transformation. For most people in that situation, we were able to move them to other roles by upskilling & cross training as the internal business know how is an asset which we didn’t like to lose. Unfortunately, we had to let go some of them in the end. We were transparent with those people and supported their outplacement. We also provided retention bonuses tied up to positively contributing to the success of the project and not letting us down in the wrong time.
Soft side of change management varied a lot. For example, in Japan there was only an email sent by the Country CEO in addition to formal trainings. Not even a flier, or a cake cutting at go live. On the contrary in Thailand, we organized cascades of events with fun components, celebrations; we covered the offices with lots of fliers about new system and handed out mouse pads with cue cards on how to do things in SAP.
I relied on a change management team provided by Accenture which performed full change management life cycle. It started with infrequent communications to all stake holders at early phases of the project with increasing content & frequencies as we approached go live. Preparedness of the users had been assessed with dip stick surveys and the messages and channels were tuned to carry them along with the project.
2)	Risk Management
Risk Management is part of daily life both during project and business as usual phases of the lifecycle of IT systems. Ideally BAU risks should be managed rigorously even at the project implementation phase, -but tend to be overshadowed by project delivery risks during project phases, as project timeline and hitting the milestones with high quality deliverables are more urgent challenges-. While it is understandable to focus on urgent/immediate risks, larger BAU risks must be kept visible and managed from early project phases too. 
I have been using simple risk registers to log the identified risks and plot them in to a matrix with likelihood & impact axis, and mitigate/manage them starting from the high likely & high impact quadrant. If there is any material risk which can’t be mitigated with the project resources in hand, I documented it and escalated to business for awareness & acceptance of the risk. 
Key point in a successful risk management process is, to ensure everyone in the team force himself/herself to spend effort to think about risks which could impact project or systems. Relying on few senior resources only, for risk management/identification will cause missing many risks and will result having to deal with the aftermath. 
When I observed that there were only few risks identified by the team members, I conducted monthly brainstorming sessions which just focused on identifying risks. Generally first sessions, didn’t produce desired output but second and third meetings turned out to be fruitful. After running three meetings, flow of risks continued at a decent volume. I repeated the process after significant staff turnover or after 2-3 years based on the flow.

Global & Cross-cultural experience

I have been working in global and cross cultural environments since I became Head of IT of Unilever Ireland in 1999.  Working on Global & cross cultural environment is my normal. Most probably I will feel as an alien in a 100% local Turkish project or team.
It is essential to understand the different cultures to succeed in projects involving people coming from different backgrounds. I don’t want to name different countries as stereotypes but I worked  with very different cultures and had to learn what it takes  to walk the journey to success with them together. I have interacted and worked with cultures who were very open & direct and did not hesitate to speak up -even more than enough-. They argued with you as if you were in a war with you; but after reaching a decision, they delivered what needs to be delivered without any monitoring/follow up. (In fact if you check their progress frequently, they get upset about that). On the contrary there were cultures which were hesitant to speak up their concerns. I had to interact with them to build their confidence to speak up and express their ideas, and challenges they see.  Some of the cultures I worked with, were motivated by eating together, having celebrations at every milestone; others were motivated by purely sticking to discipline for meeting start and end times. 
As there were always a number of cultures working together in every project, I spared time for team members to familiarize to each other by some facilitated team building sessions at the beginning of each release.
I want to mention a specific issue we faced in Japan. When my project teams visited a country for conducting design workshops, we tend to work with the country resources during normal office hours and continue working in the office until very late evening for finding solutions to the problems/requirements raised by countries during the day. Hence, we order food to the office for dinner. There is no problem in eating in the office in Japan, but it was a challenge to separate the garbage in to 25 recycling bins with some small pictures and Japanese letters which describes what needs to be put in which bin. After receiving 2 warnings from Japan team for disposing the garbage in the wrong bins, we started to carry our garbage (except the ones which were easier to determine the correct bin) to the hotel and dispose there.
column6:

Change Management:
The challenges faced during the SAP S4/HANA implementation at Agthia and the subsequent change management process to address ongoing issues post-live reveal a complex landscape of technical, organizational, and strategic obstacles. Here’s a breakdown of the key challenges and the strategic actions taken to manage and overcome these challenges:
1. Post-Implementation Performance Issues: Despite going live in 2019, Agthia encountered significant challenges with business application performance and reporting, negatively impacting productivity and posing barriers to potential expansions.
2. Vendor Transition: The maintenance solution transition from Itelligence to TechMahindra required a seamless handover to ensure continuity and efficiency, further complicated by existing system issues.
3. Unrealized Potential: The feeling within Agthia was that the SAP S4 ERP system's potential was not fully realized, leading to dissatisfaction and a need for a comprehensive review to identify and address underlying issues.

Actions Taken for Change Management:

Strategic Partnership and Assessment:
Engagement with SAP for Business Value Realization: A crucial step was forming a strategic partnership with SAP to conduct a Business Value Realization exercise. This involved a high-level assessment by SAP’s senior industry and solution specialists to pinpoint pain points and stakeholder expectations. (Sponsored by SAP UAE MD)
Utilization of SAP Pathfinder Tool: For a thorough system checkup, this tool helped identify areas of improvement and align the system’s capabilities with Agthia’s operational needs.
Executive Involvement and Leadership:
CEO Sponsorship:  • Having the CEO sponsor and lead the program was pivotal. It underscored the initiative's importance and ensured organizational alignment and commitment at the highest level. • Nominating 35 top employees to become subject matter experts (SMEs) for the program helped build an internal knowledge base, facilitating ongoing support and future deployments. • Insisting on zero customization unless approved by the CEO ensured adherence to industry standards and best practices, minimizing complications that custom solutions often introduce. • Mandatory participation from the CEO, BU heads, and key stakeholders in steering committee meetings with SAP and the project team fostered a collaborative environment, ensuring that all parties were aligned and committed to the project’s success.


The change management process for the SAP S4/HANA implementation at Agthia and Adani highlighted the importance of strategic partnerships, executive leadership, rigorous assessment, and continuous monitoring. By addressing these challenges through targeted actions and maintaining a focus on communication, training, and stakeholder engagement, Agthia worked towards realizing the full potential of its ERP system to support current operations and future growth.
	
2. Risk Management
	Shiva has held responsibility for technology risk management throughout his career. 
At Pfizer Limited, he ensured that risks associated with technology were identified, evaluated, and mitigated effectively. At Pfizer India, he consistently received "Good" Corporate Audit (US-CIA) rating for all IT processes, for three consecutive years.
At Adani, Implemented a Managed Security Service (MSSP) to enhance the company's overall IT security posture. • Strengthened cybersecurity measures to elevate data and information protection across multiple platforms. • Introduced advanced threat detection and prevention solutions to mitigate cybersecurity risks. • Conducted regular security audits to identify and address potential vulnerabilities. • Ensured compliance with various regulations and regulatory frameworks through enterprise governance, risk, and compliance solutions.
At Agthia Group PJSC, he developed and executed a forward-looking IT Roadmap spanning from 2021 to 2025, focusing on robust IT Security measures to drive operational excellence and innovation across the organization. • Enhancing the cybersecurity posture of Agthia Group involved identifying and mitigating various cyber risks across multiple platforms. • Formulating and executing a Security Maturity Roadmap demonstrates a proactive approach to cybersecurity risk management. • Identified and mitigated risks associated with the automation of sales order handling processes through the implementation of RPA technologies. • Spearheaded the successful launch of the Agthia Smart Card, which not only increased digital presence and revenues but also involved managing risks associated with digital transactions and customer data security. • Implementing SAP HANA 1709 and 2021 at Agthia Group involved significant risks due to the complexity and scale of the project. Successfully leading these implementations showcases expertise in risk management. • Managing the IT Acquisition and Integration of 5 companies in different countries required meticulous risk assessment to ensure a smooth transition and synergy extraction while minimizing disruptions. • Ensuring compliance with industry benchmarks such as ISMS (ISO27001:2013) readiness at Agthia Group demonstrates a focus on managing regulatory risks and meeting industry standards. • Leading the digitalization agenda at Agthia Group for the next 5 to 7 years involves managing operational risks associated with large-scale digital transformation initiatives, ensuring operational continuity and efficiency.
These examples demonstrate how both Shiva and the organizations he has been associated with have implemented various risk management strategies to safeguard data, enhance cybersecurity, ensure compliance, and manage technology and financial risks effectively. 	

3. Global and Cross-cultural Experience
Shiva has gained considerable global and cross-cultural experience throughout his career, having worked extensively in the United Arab Emirates, India, and other countries in APAC. At Agthia Group PJSC, Shiva demonstrated global leadership by overseeing IT operations across multiple countries, including the UAE, Egypt, Jordan, Kuwait, KSA, Turkey and Oman. • Leading the IT Acquisition and Integration of 5 companies in different countries at Agthia Group showcases experience in navigating cross-cultural challenges and harmonizing IT operations in a global context.  At Pfizer India, he managed the Asia Regional Application Shared Services (RASS) center, which supported 12 markets in APAC. • This experience allowed him to understand the nuances of operating in a multicultural setting and collaborating with stakeholders globally. • He also collaborated with a wide variety of local, regional, and global functions to accomplish a portfolio of project initiatives for Asian, Europe and US markets. 
Shiva’s experience in global IT leadership, international collaboration, cultural sensitivity, and strategic partnerships underscores his proficiency in navigating cross-cultural environments and driving technology initiatives that resonate across diverse markets and stakeholders.

Redington SAP Implementation for MEA & Redington Shared Services Implementation

Context:
Implementation ERP system was done to streamline operations, enhance efficiency, and improve data visibility. 
Shared Services Implementation was done to bring process efficiency,  FTE efficiency and improve overall transaction TAT and improve operational cost
Change Management Initiatives:
Communication Strategy: Leadership communicated the reasons for the change, benefits, and the impact on daily operations to employees at all levels through town hall meetings, emails, and training sessions.
Training Programs: Comprehensive training programs were developed to ensure employees had the necessary skills to use the new system. This included hands-on workshops, online modules, and support resources, documentation of the process and recording sessions that can be played back
Employee Involvement: Employees were actively involved in the decision-making process. Cross-functional teams were formed to provide feedback, identify challenges, and propose solutions.
Outcome:
Despite initial resistance and challenges, the company successfully transitioned to the SAP system. Employees adapted to the change, and the organisation experienced improved efficiency, data accuracy, and overall operational effectiveness.
Shared services the FTE that were impacted was not so pleased with the decision when the transition was happening. But others stepped in to ensure we successfully transition and released the benefits of having SSC

Redington Cloud Reseller Platform Development and Launch

Context:
Redington decided to build a cloud resell platform as its own IP/ Product. All the platforms evaluated were on a revenue share model and did not have all the functionality. The second key challenge is enabling partners to have visibility into what actions are taken on the platform and give a detailed action, usage, and billing report. Ensure transparency. Integration with Hyperscaler’s was a challenge and when we started real-time reporting was not there.

Risk Management Strategies:
Market Research: Thorough market research was conducted to understand partner needs, preferences, and potential challenges. This helped in identifying potential risks associated with market acceptance.
Prototyping and Testing: We adopted an iterative prototyping approach, allowing for continuous testing and refinement of the product based on user feedback. This minimised the risk of launching a product that needed to meet customer expectations.
Collaboration with Experts: To mitigate technological risks, we collaborated with industry experts, both internally and externally. External consultants provided insights, and cross-functional teams within the company ensured a holistic approach to risk management.
Outcome:
By actively managing risks, Redington launched the platform, gained partner confidence, rollout out to other contries in the region and subsequently across geographies and adapted to emerging challenges. The risk mitigation strategies contributed to a more resilient product development process. Business grew to 500 Million US$ over last 4 years

Context:

Cultural Training: The organization provided cultural training programs to employees, emphasizing cultural awareness, communication styles, and collaboration practices.
Diversity and Inclusion Initiatives: The leadership promoted diversity and inclusion initiatives to foster a sense of belonging among employees from different backgrounds. This included the establishment of employee resource groups and mentorship programs.
Localized Leadership Teams: Regional/ country leadership teams were formed, ensuring that decision-making considered local nuances and cultural considerations.

Outcome:
The helped the team to be successful, and the Redington achieved a unified corporate culture that embraced diversity. The cross-cultural strategies improved collaboration, innovation, and employee satisfaction across the organization.

column3: Using your experience, elaborate your understanding of how to design and manage global solution templates, ensuring they cater to both global standardization and local customization needs.
column4:
During both my previous stints we had faced the challenge of standardising the IT solution for the group while maintaining the flexiblity required for individual businesses either due to diverse nature of the businesses or different geographies having peculiar requirements.  In IFFCO, we decided to go for the 'single version of truth' and implement SAP.  We picked up two pilot countries (Indonesia & Egypt) where the IT solution  needed immediate intervention compared to other geographies where the legacy system was working reasonably well.  While designing the solution, we focused on creating a global template by involving key BPOs (business process owners) in other verticals.  There are common processes like Procurement, Accounts Payable, Accounts Receivable, Accounts closing and reporting, warehousing and inventory management, etc. irrespective of the business type or geography.  Such processes became part of the global template and got standardised while incorporating best practices across the organisation.  Wherever there were company/geography specific processes, those were mapped into the new system.  This entire exercise gave us the benefits of standardisation as well as catered to the unique local processes that required customisation.  This ensured that the customisation was kept to the bare minimum required and the standard software was utilised to the best of its capacity. 

SAP Rating on 
Template Strategy Expertise: 4
Global & Corss cultural exp - 4
Experience in Scalable rollouts - 4
column5:
My entire career has been about finding the balance between globalization & standardization versus different & specific requirements/practices in the countries. Unilever is an FMCG company. Compared to Sharaf group, from product portfolio and high level process point of view, there are more similarities amongst the countries in Unilever. Yet, there are major differences amongst the companies due to realities of the countries.  For example, in Australia you have to operate dark factories due to high human resource cost, but in some geographies, even purchasing a Hand Held Terminal for managing the inventory accurately is financially infeasible. In some markets a handful of customers make up 80 % of the turnover and in others you have to interact with thousands of smaller customers. In some countries you can operate with wide credit limits with little control, in some countries you can’t ship anything until you see the cash in your bank account. 
In order to be successful in finding the right balance, it is necessary to categorize business processes and technical solutions in to 4 Categories. 
1)	Processes/capabilities which must be standardized and the reasons for standardizations.
2)	Processes/Capabilities which must be standardized with several options which companies/markets can choose from the agreed process variations.
3)	Processes/Capabilities specific to a particular business which can be implemented without risking the resilience of the system at incremental cost of ownership, delivering business value.
4)	Processes/Capabilities specific to a particular business which can NOT be implemented without risking the resilience of the SAP system

In order to make this work, Business Process & IT experts need to work together at the beginning of the project to define the scope of the template (1 & 2). After completion of that piece of work a Design Authority Team needs to be formed to gatekeep the template and principles.
-1 & 4 are non-negotiables and demands against these should not be accommodated, unless the implications for granting the exception is well understood and accepted by the most senior executive manager. 
- For category 2; Design Authority would recommend an option, but business can choose any option. Design Authority will explain implications and pros-cons of the options. 
- For Category 3, a mechanism needs to be established by the process and IT experts to challenge the deviation demands and expect the requester to justify that value delivered is worth the cost & complication which will be carried forward during the application life cycle. Additionally, there has to be a quota which can be specified with various metrics such as total effort/number of line of code etc. Based on my experience to date, the requester claims every change request is essential. Most effective way to retain a decently harmonized system is forcing leadership of the requesting country/business make the prioritization based on an upfront agreed  quota or paying the total cost of ownership of the deviation + a premium.

I am not stating that I implemented above  framework 100 %, but I used it as much as possible taking the organizational forces and dynamics in to account. I believe this is one of the reasons why the U2K2 system is still working very well so that business is struggling to establish business case for S4HANA implementation.   

I would like to point out that, it is necessary to be very careful in deciding which business entities can coexist on a single SAP instance. There will be catastrophic consequences if businesses with large variations in processes, availability requirements & control characteristics are put together in a single instance. In Sharaf Group case, this needs to be carefully studied before instance/template strategy is decided. Even if the conclusion may be implementing multiple template/instances, common practices & processes must be followed as much as possible to reduce implementation cost and total cost of ownership.
column6:
SAP Rating on 
Template Strategy Expertise: 2
Global & Cross cultural exp - 4
Experience in Scalable rollouts - 4
To design and manage global solution templates that cater to both global standardization and local customization needs, I recommend the following:
 
Assess Specific Needs: It's important to assess the specific needs of each business unit and select solutions that align with their unique requirements while contributing to the overall standardization goals of the organization. Conduct a thorough analysis of both global and local business requirements to identify commonalities and differences across regions/business entities. Engage with stakeholders from different regions/business entities to gather insights into their specific needs and challenges. This understanding is essential to design solution templates that can be standardized globally while allowing for necessary local adaptations. Incorporate flexibility within the templates to allow for localization based on regional requirements. This could involve configurable options, language support, regulatory compliance variations, and cultural considerations. Define 
Standardization and Consolidation: Establish a set of core global standards and best practices that form the foundation of the solution templates. Develop a standardized framework that outlines the core functionalities, processes, and best practices that need to be consistent across all regions. This framework serves as the foundation for global solution templates. Define parameters for where customization is permissible within the solution templates to address specific regional requirements without compromising global alignment. These standards should reflect the organization's overarching goals and ensure consistency in key processes and functionalities across all regions. Sharaf Group should also consider consolidating its IT infrastructure and standardizing across different business units to lead to cost savings, ease of management, as well as improved data sharing and greater control of security and access protocols
Cloud-based Solutions: Sharaf Group should deploy cloud-based global solutions that overcome geographic legal requirements, languages, currencies, and cultural differences. This will enable the organization to store, process, and access data from anywhere in the world, automate routine tasks, streamline workflows, and collaborate with remote workers in real-time.
Systematic Approach to Business Digitalization: Sharaf Group should adopt a systematic approach to business digitalization to reach specific goals. This approach needs an able DTO (Digital Transformation Office) team that will guide the journey from envisioning to realization.
Engage External Consultants: Sharaf Group should engage external consultants to conduct a detailed gap analysis exercise by business area to identify core operations that need systems investment and where reengineering the current systems is essential.
Standardization of Key Business Processes: Standardizing key business processes such as P2P, receivables management, fixed asset management, and treasury and payment management can help the Sharaf Group drive operational efficiency, reduce costs, and improve customer and supplier relationships.
Governance and Change Management: Implement robust governance mechanisms to oversee the design and deployment of global solution templates. Establish clear guidelines for managing changes, approvals, and version control to ensure consistency and compliance with global standards.
Regular Review and Benchmarking: Conduct regular reviews and benchmarking exercises to assess the effectiveness of the global solution templates in meeting both global standardization and local customization needs. Use performance metrics and feedback to drive ongoing enhancements and optimizations.
By implementing these recommendations, Sharaf Group can design and manage global solution templates that cater to both global standardization and local customization needs. This will enable the organization to optimize its IT infrastructure, drive digital transformation, and achieve greater standardization and consistency across business units while ensuring alignment with overarching Sharaf Group standards and governance
column7:
SAP Rating on 
Template Strategy Expertise: 4
Global & Corss cultural exp - 4
Experience in Scalable rollouts - 4
1. Understand the Business Landscape:
Global Standardization:
Identify core business processes and functionalities that can be standardized globally for efficiency, consistency, and cost-effectiveness.
Define the global standardization requirements based on best practices and compliance standards.
Local Customization:
Understand local market nuances, regulatory requirements, and cultural differences.
Identify areas where local customization is essential to meet specific business needs and ensure compliance.

2. Define a Governance Structure:
Establish a governance structure that balances central control with local autonomy.
Form a global steering committee comprising representatives from different regions to oversee the design, implementation, and ongoing management of the solution templates.

3. Develop a Modular Architecture:
Create a modular solution architecture that allows for flexibility and scalability.
Define core modules that adhere to global standards and can be easily customized or extended to accommodate local variations.

4. Standardize Data Management:
Implement a standardized approach to data management, ensuring data integrity and consistency globally.
Define data models, taxonomy, and standards that serve as a foundation for both global and local data requirements.

5. Local Requirements Assessment:
Engage with local teams to assess specific requirements, such as legal, regulatory, or market-specific needs.
Conduct thorough gap analysis to identify areas where customization is necessary without compromising global standardization.

Customization Framework:
Develop a customization framework that allows local teams to tailor the solution templates within defined parameters.
Clearly document customization guidelines, ensuring alignment with global standards and avoiding divergent developments.

7. Collaboration and Communication:
Open communication channels between global and local teams.
Facilitate collaboration through regular meetings, workshops, and shared platforms to discuss requirements, challenges, and best practices.

8. Training and Change Management:
Provide comprehensive training programs for both global and local teams on the usage and customization of the solution templates.
Implement change management strategies to address cultural aspects and ensure smooth adoption.

9. Continuous Improvement:
Establish feedback mechanisms for ongoing improvement.
Encourage local teams to share insights and lessons learned, facilitating continuous refinement of global solution templates.

10. Monitoring and Metrics:
Regularly assess the impact of customizations on both global and local levels to identify opportunities for optimization.

11. Scalability and Upgradability:
Design the solution templates with scalability in mind to accommodate future growth.
Ensure that global standards and local customizations are seamlessly integrated during system upgrades.

12. Compliance and Risk Management:
Regularly audit local customizations to ensure compliance with global standards and regulatory requirements.
Implement risk management strategies to mitigate potential challenges associated with customization.

column3: Why are you considering a change from your present role and why are you considering us?
column4: I had taken a planned career break after working non stop for 3 decades.  After working for 5 years in IFFCO, I worked with the board, got a golden visa in UAE, transitioned my role to my direct report as part of succession planning and took a break for few months.  I used the time to travel (both sons are in the US), work on my fitness and caught on few personal pending items.  I feel completely rejuvernated and refreshed.  I am ready to take on the next challenging assignment.   Sharaf group is a well diversified and respected group for carrying out the business in an ethical manner.  My previous two roles with IFFCO and Tata Consumer were group level senior positions where I had the opportunity to create a digital roadmap, execute and deliver the business benefits.  I see a similar opportunity with Sharaf group to deliver business value at an expedited pace.
column5:
There are mainly two reasons why I am seeking a new role.
1) Unilever's current IT position in SAP is pretty much keeping the status quo. However, I would like to continue being part of major transformations, S4 implementations and new challenges.
2) Turkish economy is not doing well nowadays. While salaries are adjusted multiple times to match inflation/devaluation, it is stressful to withdraw  salary from the bank every month and hand carry it to foreign exchange kiosk for converting to hard currency. I would like to have peace of mind on financial aspects and focus on doing my job.
column6:
The reason for change I have as looking at opportunities for larger role in an organization which is looking at phenomenal growth and revenues and is embarking on IT and Digital transformation to the next level, which will be an exciting career opportunity for me as well. 

1. Challenging Environment:
Sharaf Group operates in 59 countries, presenting complex legal, language, currency, and cultural challenges.
The opportunity to tackle these challenges head-on and create a cohesive IT strategy across diverse markets could be highly appealing to someone like me who enjoys working in dynamic environments. 

2. Opportunity for Growth and Impact:
Sharaf Group's IT landscape requires significant standardization, consolidation, and optimization efforts.
Joining Sharaf Group as a Group CIO would give me the chance to leave a lasting mark on the organization by enhancing its IT landscape and driving digital transformation.

By taking on the role of Group CIO at Sharaf Group, I would have the opportunity to apply his extensive experience in IT transformation, risk management, and global and cross-cultural experience to create a resilient and adaptive IT infrastructure capable of supporting the organization's ambitious growth plans.

I think the mix of my Business Technology (BT)  knowledge, strategy, deep commercial knowledge, effectively delivering outcomes by leveraging the strength of a matrix organisation and a sustained ability to always deliver on initiatives will help move the Sharaf Group organization to the next level and in the next phase of growth.
column7:
Looking for new opportunities, challenges and learning

Sharaf as an organization has diversified interest in Shipping, Logistics, Retail etc. I feel my experience can help the organization in a great way and also help me learn new things

column3: What is your aspiration - professional or personal
column4: For my last two stints, I have worked at the Group level with the board members and senior leaders to craft the digital roadmap and execute it, leading to significant business benefits.  I would like to use that experience and knowledge to bring in transformation at a group like Sharaf.  I would also like to build a team of IT professionals to support the digital initiatives and have the talent pipeline to continuously innovate and leverage new technologies.  At a personal level, I would like to maintain a goo work life balance so that I am performing at the optimal level for extended periods of time.
column5: Aspiring to leverage my skills and experiences in Information Technology especially in SAP, to contribute meaningfully to a dynamic team or organization in its SAP journey. I want  to establish a long lasting positive impact to business by contributing in building a strong ERP platform. I would love to work with a team with ambitions to face challenges and work to achieve stretching goals.
column6:
My professional aspiration, as outlined in the provided resume, includes leveraging my extensive experience and expertise in technology leadership to drive digital transformation, enhance business performance, and support organizational growth. 

I aim to continue playing a strategic role in leading technology initiatives, fostering innovation, and delivering impactful solutions that generate a competitive edge and accelerate business success . 

My career achievements demonstrate a track record of driving change, facilitating advancements, and providing superior technology and business leadership. My primary motivation is to continue growing professionally and making meaningful contributions to the organizations I serve.

On a personal level, I aspire to further develop my leadership skills, expand my  professional network, and contribute to the advancement of the industries I serve. Additionally, I seek opportunities for continuous learning and growth, both professionally and personally, to stay at the forefront of technological advancements and industry best practices.
column7:
Professional Aspirations:
Digital Transformation Leadership: Aspire to lead the organization through a successful digital transformation, leveraging emerging technologies for increased efficiency and competitiveness.
Innovation and Technology Adoption: Aim to foster a culture of innovation within the IT department, driving the adoption of cutting-edge technologies that contribute to the organization's growth.
Strategic Alignment: Strive to align IT strategies with overall business objectives, ensuring that technology initiatives directly contribute to the success of the organization.
Cybersecurity Excellence: Aspire to establish and maintain robust cybersecurity measures, safeguarding the organization's sensitive data and ensuring resilience against cyber threats.
Global IT Leadership: Seek opportunities to expand IT influence globally, especially in organizations with a multinational presence, by implementing standardized global IT solutions.
Thought Leadership: Aspire to become a thought leader in the technology domain, contributing to industry discussions, conferences, and publications.

Personal Aspirations:
Leadership Development: Personal goal to mentor and develop the skills of the IT team, fostering a culture of continuous learning and professional growth.
Work-Life Balance: Aspire to achieve a healthy work-life balance, ensuring personal well-being while managing the demands of a high-level executive role.
Professional Networking: Expand personal and professional networks by connecting with industry peers, thought leaders, and professionals in related fields.
Continuous Learning: Personal commitment to staying abreast of technological advancements, industry trends, and leadership best practices through continuous learning and education.
Social Responsibility: Aspire to integrate social responsibility into the organization's IT strategy, contributing to sustainability, diversity, and corporate social responsibility initiatives.
Personal Fulfillment: Want to heep my hobbies active (Reef keeping and Photography), Travel, spend time with family and friends

column3: What support do you need from Sharaf Group to achieve your aspiration?
column4: To achieve the above aspiration, I would need the support and guidance from the board and senior leadership.  Together we can create magic!
column5: I would need Sharaf Group's support in building a strong team to succeed.
column6:
To achieve my aspirations effectively, I would likely benefit from the following support from Sharaf Group:

1. Investment in Technology Infrastructure:
Sharaf Group can support me by providing adequate investment in technology infrastructure to implement my proposed IT transformation roadmap. This includes funding for cloud computing initiatives, cybersecurity solutions, and business intelligence tools.

2. Organizational Alignment:
Ensuring organizational alignment and buy-in across different business units within Sharaf Group is crucial for the successful implementation of IT transformation initiatives. I would require support from senior management to drive alignment and collaboration among various stakeholders.

3. Resource Allocation:
Sharaf Group can assist me by allocating the necessary resources, both in terms of skilled IT professionals and budget, to execute the IT roadmap effectively. This includes providing support for building high-performance IT teams and engaging key IT partners.

4. Change Management Support:
Implementing IT transformation often involves significant changes in processes, systems, and organizational culture. Sharaf Group can provide change management support to help me navigate these transitions smoothly and ensure successful adoption of new technologies and practices.

5. Training and Development:
Offering training and development opportunities for IT staff within Sharaf Group can enhance their skills and capabilities, aligning them with my vision for technology leadership and innovation. Continuous learning and upskilling are essential for driving successful IT transformations.

6. Clear Communication Channels:
Establishing clear communication channels within the organization can facilitate effective information sharing, feedback mechanisms, and transparency regarding IT initiatives. Sharaf Group can support me by fostering a culture of open communication and collaboration.
column7:
Executive Leadership Support
Investment and Resources
Collaborative Organizational Culture
Open Communication Channels
Adoption of Emerging Technologies
Flexibility and Agility
Recognition of IT's Strategic Role
Strategic Partnerships
Risk & Change Management Support
